causes: European companies acquired resource and trade monopolies in Persia.
Persian resentment over foreign economic control.
British and Russian-backed firms began enforcing private armies to secure their operations.
events_leading_up_to_war: The British East India Company secured a monopoly over Persian silk and opium production.
Russian traders expanded fur and caviar exports in northern Persia, displacing local markets.
The Persian government attempted to revoke unfair treaties, leading to violent clashes.

result.territorial_changes: Persian Gulf and Caspian trade zones remain under foreign control.

European_Companies.troops: 5,000 private soldiers, mercenaries, and company militias
European_Companies.artillery: Privately owned cannons and British-supplied rifles

major_battles.name: Battle of Bandar Abbas
major_battles.description: Persian forces attempted to seize back a key trading post, but were repelled by European private militias.
major_battles.outcome: European victory, reinforcing control over the Persian Gulf.

major_battles.name: Siege of Rasht
major_battles.description: Russian-backed traders and private soldiers defended their outposts from a major Persian counterattack.
major_battles.outcome: Russian victory, securing Caspian Sea trade routes.

texts.name: Anglo-Persian Trade Treaties
texts.details: These documents outline European companies’ economic rights in Persia and the conflict's aftermath.

texts.name: Persian Military Reports
texts.details: Reports describing battles against European-backed forces and failed attempts to reclaim lost land.

archaeological_evidence.description: Ruins of British and Russian trading outposts fortified during the conflict.
Bullets, cannons, and broken Persian banners found near Rasht and Bandar Abbas.

historical_texts.name: Persian Resistance Chronicles
historical_texts.details: Records from Persian officials describing resistance efforts and European interference.

historical_texts.name: Company War Logs
historical_texts.details: Private correspondence between European traders and military officers discussing strategy.

political: Persia was forced to accept more European economic control.
Led to increased resentment and later anti-foreign uprisings.
long_term_effects: Foreshadowed future Persian conflicts with European powers over economic sovereignty.
Weakened Persia’s economy and military control over trade zones.

military: Showed the power of private military forces in shaping colonial and economic policy.
Demonstrated the weakness of Persia’s military against modernized private armies.
political: Expanded European dominance in Persian trade.
Led to future uprisings against foreign economic control.
cultural: Persian nationalism grew in response to the conflict.
Led to later Persian constitutional reforms to resist foreign influence.
